items.title: Reference = External State
items.content: Just as Ralph persists state to files rather than relying on context memory, Reference docs externalize numbers that would otherwise live in your head. The principle: "If it's not written down, it doesn't exist."

items.title: How to use Reference docs
items.content:
Beginner: Look up specific prices
Intermediate: Compare patterns by cost
Advanced: Build cost models for decisions
Staff: Design organizational cost governance

items.title: Model Selection Dilemma
items.content:
Haiku: 80% cheaper, but loses track in long sessions
Sonnet: Balanced, but occasional hallucinations
Opus: Best quality, but too slow/expensive for routine tasks

Heuristic: "Haiku for setup, Sonnet for builds, Opus for reviews"

items.title: When subscription beats API
items.content:
Below $20/month usage: API wins
$20-100/month: Pro subscription wins
$100-200/month: Max 5x wins
Above $200/month: Max 20x or API depending on predictability

Key variable: Is your usage predictable or bursty?

items.title: YC Hackathon: $297 for 6 repos
items.content: Teams ran Ralph loops overnight across 6+ repositories for under $50 each. Key insight: Task decomposition quality drives cost more than raw iteration count.

items.title: How costs spiral
items.content:
$5 session: Focused, well-planned
$15 session: Scope creep, context growing
$50 session: Debugging in circles, should have reset
$150+ session: Runaway Ralph loop, no iteration limits

Prevention: Set MAX_ITERATIONS before every Ralph run.

items.title: The one number to remember
items.content:
$6/day average.

If you're spending significantly more, you're either doing heavy automation (expected) or have inefficiencies to fix (check model selection and context management).

items.title: Token costs = Cloud compute
items.content:
Spot instances = Batch API (50% off, async)
Reserved instances = Subscription (predictable)
On-demand = Standard API (flexible)
Savings plans = Prompt caching (up to 90% off)

Same optimization patterns apply.

items.title: Cost + Context Management
items.content: Context efficiency directly affects cost. A 200K token session costs 3-4x a 50K session. The context management guide explains how to stay efficient. The cost reference shows what the numbers are.

items.title: If cost reference isn't what you need
items.content:
Architecture decisions? See Judgment Guide
Pattern selection? See Complexity Ladder
Context optimization? See Context Management
Multi-agent costs? See Multi-Agent Mastery

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal cost prediction
items.content: No reliable way to predict session costs before starting. Token usage varies wildly based on file sizes, tool calls, and model "thinking". Best practice: Monitor with /cost every 30 minutes.
